docs.title: Home
docs.text:
For our store, please visit phasebyte.com.

Thanks for visiting our docs. You'll find everything you need to know about PhaseByte here. If you need further help, just send us an email at hello@phasebyte.com.

  • 01 // PhaseOne

    Everything you need to know about the PhaseOne.

    Lets go!

  • 02 // Deskmats

    Taking care of your PhaseByte deskmats.

    Lets go!

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The PhaseOne is the first keyboard PhaseByte made. The first batch of produced boards are the Founder's Edition, which are individually sequenced 1 through 50 by a milled engraving on the back.

  • Build Guide

    Everything you need to know to build the PhaseOne.

    Getting started

  • Functionality

    Bluetooth, LED Bar Controls and more.

    See more

  • Modifications

    What PhaseOne owners do to improve their board.

    Lets do it

  • Improvements & Troubleshooting

    Known bugs, quirks, and what to improve in later revisions.

    We're working on

  • Firmware Updates

    How to and newest updates to PhaseOne firmware.

    Level up

Batch 1 of the Founders Edition PhaseOnes were released late July 2024. Only a few boards have been spotted... so far.

PhaseOne Tracker :

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The PhaseOne uses the latest and in our opinion, greatest, open-source firmware, ZMK. It supports Bluetooth and Wired keyboard operation and is built by a great community of contributors. Within a few months, ZMK will have a webpage to ZMK Studio to easily further customize your board without any coding ability.

docs.title: Layout
docs.text: The PhaseOne ships with configuration to support up to 5 Bluetooth connections and Wired performance with the following keymap:

docs.title: Normal Keymap
docs.text: The normal keymap is a legend of what occurs when pressing a specific key.

docs.title: Fn Layer Keymap
docs.text: The Fn or function keymap is a legend of what occurs when holding down the Fn key and pressing another key.

docs.title: Charging
docs.text: The PhaseOne automatically charges when connected to a USB outlet with a USB-C cable. You can tell the PhaseOne is charging when the LED on the back of the board under the space bar is illuminated. When completed charging, the LED will turn off.

docs.title: Bluetooth
docs.text: The PhaseOne Bluetooth functionality supports 5 profiles (5 different stored connections to devices). The profiles allow you to quickly switch between connected devices.

docs.title: Pairing with Bluetooth
docs.text:
To pair a device with the PhaseOne, like your computer, phone, or other device:

  1. Select the profile you want to store the connection on. You can do this by pressing the Fn key and 1,2,3,4, or 5.
  2. Once on the selected profile, the PhaseOne automatically starts pairing mode and will display as "PhaseOne".
  3. On the device you’d like to connect to, pull up the Bluetooth menu and select PhaseOne. Depending on the device, this can take a couple tries.
  4. Once the connected device says pairing successful, you’re good to go!

docs.title: Clearing and Repairing with Bluetooth
docs.text:
For security reasons in ZMK, you cannot pair a new device to a profile on PhaseOne until the selected profile is cleared. To clear a profile:

  1. First select the profile you would like to clear using Fn key and 1,2,3,4, or 5.
  2. Use the Fn key + Del to clear the selected profile

docs.title: Bluetooth Controls
docs.text: Method Description Fn + 1 Pair/Connect to Device 1 Fn + 2 Pair/Connect to Device 2 Fn + 3 Pair/Connect to Device 3 Fn + 4 Pair/Connect to Device 4 Fn + 5 Pair/Connect to Device 5 Fn + Delete Clear Currently Selected Bluetooth Connections

docs.title: LED Bar Controls
docs.text: Method Description Fn + F1 LED On/Off Fn + F2 Decrease LED Brightness Fn + F3 Increase LED Brightness Fn + F4 Cycle LED Colour Fn + F5 Cycle LED Pattern Fn + F6 Decrease LED Saturation Fn + F7 Increase LED Saturation

docs.title: Media Controls
docs.text: Method Description Fn + F8 Decrease Screen Brightness Fn + F9 Increase Screen Brightness Fn + F10 Skip Previous Fn + F11 Play/Pause Fn + F12 Skip Next Fn + Home Mute Audio Fn + Print Decrease Volume Fn + Insert Increase Volume

docs.title: All Controls
docs.text: Method Description Fn + F1 LED On/Off Fn + F2 Decrease LED Brightness Fn + F3 Increase LED Brightness Fn + F4 Cycle LED Colour Fn + F5 Cycle LED Pattern Fn + F6 Decrease LED Saturation Fn + F7 Increase LED Saturation Fn + F8 Decrease Screen Brightness Fn + F9 Increase Screen Brightness Fn + F10 Skip Previous Fn + F11 Play/Pause Fn + F12 Skip Next Fn + Home Mute Audio Fn + Print Decrease Volume Fn + Insert Increase Volume Fn + 1 Pair/Connect to Device 1 Fn + 2 Pair/Connect to Device 2 Fn + 3 Pair/Connect to Device 3 Fn + 4 Pair/Connect to Device 4 Fn + 5 Pair/Connect to Device 5 Fn + Delete Clear Currently Selected Bluetooth Connections

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Here you'll find a video guide and a written guide on how to build your PhaseOne.

docs.title: 1. Contents and Unboxing
docs.text:
First things first, make sure your kit has everything you need. Your kit should include:

  • Top Case with a LED diffuser
  • Bottom Case with an installed daughter board and forged carbon fiber shields
  • PhaseByte wave pouch with silicone gaskets (12) and feet (4)
  • PCB (Printed Circuit Board)
  • Forged Carbon Plate

Optionally, your kit may also include:

  • Foam Kit with Poron Gaskets (6)
  • FR4 Plate
  • Durock V3 Stabilizers

docs.title: 2. How to Open and Close the Case
docs.text:
The case uses a magnetic closure with really strong magnets. The easiest way to open the case is to place your fingers around the edges of the top case and your thumbs on the base. Now, push down with your thumbs and pull up with your fingers.

The easiest way to close the case is to align the top of the case first. The magnets are strong enough to hold the assembly closed, so they're also strong enough to lift the base. To avoid any damage, after aligning the top of the case, use your thumbs to hold down the base while slowly lowering the top case.

docs.title: 3. Testing the PCB
docs.text:
The last thing you want is to build a keyboard with a bad socket. We’ve tested the PCB but just in case, you should test it too. Here’s how:

  1. Grab some tweezers or some wire.

  2. Plug in the PCB to the daughter board with the preinstalled ribbon cable. To do so, first unlatch the header. Make sure the blue part of the cable faces towards you and the gold part faces towards the PCB. When inserted, it should be past this jumper. Once inserted, just lock the header back in place.

  3. Grab a USB-C cable and plug in the board.

  4. Navigate to https://usevia.app/test and turn on key sounds for a little more fun.

  5. With the tweezer or jumper of your choice, connect the two metal contacts for each switch together.

  6. Note, the FN key won’t light up as it’s a ZMK layer key. If your board looks like this, you’re good to go.

docs.title: 4. Installing the Feet and Gaskets
docs.text:
For the feet, remove the 3M film and place the feet in the 4 slots on the back of the base.

For the gaskets, place 6 on the bottom case slots and 6 on the top case slots. Note, there are 4 slots across the top and two slots along the bottom.

We recommend only using the Poron gaskets on the base for the best fit.

docs.title: 5. Stabilizers
docs.text:
If you’ve got stabs from us or somewhere else, we highly recommend lubing them. There’s plenty of guides out there so we won’t bore you with that, just YouTube “How to Lube Stabilizers” (we like Taeha Types version).

For the PhaseOne, we need 3 shorts stabilizers (2u) and 1 long stabilizer (6.25u). The shorter of the two long stabilizers in the kit. The long stabilizer is for the space bar, and the shorter ones are for the backspace, enter, and left shift key.

To install them, place the board with the socket side down (the side with the screen printing). Place the clip in the end of the larger hole and the screw in the end of the smaller hole. Then flip the board over and place a washer and finally the screw.

docs.title: 6. Foam and Plate
docs.text: Once the stabilizers are installed you can place the optional foam on top and then the plate. Note, on some foam kits we noticed that the stabilizer bar contacts the foam. If this issue causes fit issues with your build, please cut away the small bit of foam over the stabilizers.

docs.title: 7. Installing Switches and Keycaps
docs.text:
You pretty much just pop these in but you must make sure they go in straight and the pins do not bend. To make sure, take a quick look at the bottom of the switch. If the pins are straight you are good to go. If not, straighten with tweezers. You can check if they’re installed correctly by flipping over the board and visually checking if you can see the pin between the socket.

Be sure to place the switches fully into the board.

Once the switches are installed, place your keycaps of choice on top.

docs.title: 8. Final Assembly
docs.text:
Lastly, connect the PCB back to the daughter board. Note that the cable will twist.

Place the assembly into the case.

Make sure it's an equal distance from both sides. Snap on the top case and there you have it - a fully assembled PhaseOne.

To open the case again, place your thumb on the left alt key and left arrow key. Push down with your thumbs and lift with your fingers.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
The first thing to check is your USB-C cable. It is a known issue that many cable makers using different specifications for how close the protective jacket or heat shrink is to the end of the metal connector on the cable. Potentially, this stops the cable from making a good connection with the board. You can fix this issue by trying a different cable, or getting a cable specifically for mechanical keyboards.

For more information please check our Improvements Tab or contact us, we'd love to help!

docs.title: 3 // Modifications
docs.text: Please send us an email if you'd like to add anything you've found out to our list.

docs.title: Lubing Stabilizers
docs.text: You probably already know this one, but lubing your stabilizers dramatically improves the sound when pressing Space, Shift, Enter, and Backspace. You'll need a few extra tools and a little but of time but we highly recommend doing this to truly hear the tone of the PhaseOne. If you'd like to learn how, any YouTube tutorial should do!

docs.title: Lubing Switches
docs.text: Another one you probably already know, lubing your switches or making sure to purchase pre-lubed switches. You'll need a few extra tools like before and a lot more time but we highly recommend doing this or buying pre-lubed switches. If you'd like to learn how, any YouTube tutorial should do for the specific switches you are using!

docs.title: Tape Mod
docs.text: Some owners have used a thin tape to eliminate the high frequencies of certain switch and plate combinations. To do this, they apply tape on the across the entire back of the PCB (printed daughter board or electrical assembly).

docs.title: Foam Kit Modification
docs.text: Some owners have cut away some of the supporting material between the function row (R1) and the number row (R2) to allow better pass through of the LEDs from the PCB (printed daughter board or electrical assembly), through to the LED bar.

docs.title: Quality of Life
docs.text: None yet!

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: If you cannot find an issue you are having on this list, please let us know so we can make future PhaseOnes even better. And through software, maybe even the one you already have!

docs.title: Mechanical
docs.text: Issue Fix Although very strong, the magnets cannot compress the case fully closed when using Poron gaskets on the top and bottom. Currently, you can get the same type feel by using the Silicon gaskets on the top and the softer Poron gaskets on the bottom. Some cables do not fit. Known cables that do not work: Apple USB-C to USB-C, Glorious Gaming Cable. Try various USB-C cables or use a cable meant for mechanical keyboards from providers like Onyx Cables or Dispatch. We are currently working on a tech flex, affordable cable we can offer with the PhaseOne.

docs.title: Electrical
docs.text: Issue Fix The cable connecting the daughter board to the main board is twisted when installed correctly. This does not affect performance, and the ribbon cable is designed to withstand folding and bending. However, we will make sure future iterations utilize a new daughter board with a corrected orientation header. Green light when unplugging the USB-C cable from the PhaseOne. We are still determining the cause of this bug, but it can be quickly fixed by using the LED controls to toggle the LED on/off. (Fn + F1) The keyboard freezes or only works using bluetooth. We have found that in most cases the cable connecting the daughter board is either improperly seated into the main board or has come loose. By opening the case and reseating the flat cable, the issue is resolved.

docs.title: Wireless
docs.text: Issue Fix Windows machines using the specific Intel AX200 Bluetooth Chip have intermittent connectivity issues like disconnecting. Unfortunately, this issue cannot be fixed with the PhaseOne.

docs.title: 5 // Firmware
docs.text: Here, you'll find any firmware updates! Of course, you can always customize your firmware using ZMK. However, from time to time we will release updates to make sure everyone is leveling up with us!

docs.title: ZMK Studio
docs.text:
In this update you'll find compatibility to remap your keys using ZMK's newest addition, ZMK Studio. It allows any PhaseOne (with the newest firmware) to update their layout using a web browser.

To install a new update, first download the firmware file from our Google Drive link, here: Firmware Link

Once you have the file, follow these steps:

  1. Remove your space bar from the PhaseOne.
  2. Underneath and through the plate, you'll find a little button on the PCB. This is the reset button.
  3. Plug in your PhaseOne to your computer using a USB-C cable.
  4. Press the reset button twice. You should see a folder pop up on your computer titled PhaseOne.
  5. This is the boot loader where you can drag and drop firmware updates.
  6. Drag the new firmware file into the PhaseOne folder.
  7. The keyboard should automatically close the folder and be ready for use!

docs.title: How to Use ZMK Studio
docs.text:
To remap your keys, use the following setups:

  1. Plug in your PhaseOne to your computer using a USB-C cable.
  2. Navigate to ZMK Studio in your browser.
  3. Select PhaseOne from the dropdown.
  4. To unlock your keyboard, use (Fn + Escape).
  5. Using your mouse you can click on a key and update what the key should do on press.
  6. Use the button in the top right to push your changes.
  7. Enjoy.

Please note, ZMK Studio is in alpha. The PhaseOne is one of the first board to have access.

MISSING!

If you spot a PhaseOne, please let us know immediately! It is a matter of importance. Email us at hello@phasebyte.com with the following details:

  • switches used
  • keycaps used
  • any modifications
  • and photo proof

A REWARD WILL BE PROVIDED.

docs.title: Cleaning
docs.text: All our deskmats are hand and machine washable. We do recommended hand washing for keeping the lifespan of your deskmat as long as possible.

docs.title: Hand Washing
docs.text:
We have lots of videos on our TikTok watching our deskmats, but here are the instructions if you need them!

  1. In a bathtub or sink, wet the entire deskmat with luke warm water.
  2. Using a mild detergent, pour the cleaning liquid on the deskmat.
  3. Depending on the level of the stains or spill, scrub lightly or with more force to remove any mess. Be careful not to go too intense on the printed stitched edges of the mat. You won't be able to remove the ink but you could cause preemptive fraying.
  4. Rinse all the cleaning solution off of the deskmat.
  5. Print side down, place the deskmat in a towel and roll the deskmat with the towel.
  6. Let it dry for 24 hours.

docs.title: Machine Washing
docs.text:
If you want to quickly clean your deskmat you can also use a washing machine.

  1. Place your deskmat in the washing.
  2. Use a cold cycle with a mild detergent.
  3. Hang to dry.
